Cards.title: Glycine & Succinyl CoA
Cards.content:
Glycine & Succinyl is the Starting materials of heme synthesis

1.    The amino acid glycine is the sole nitrogenous precursor for the synthesis of the protoporphyrin of hemoglobin . The synthesis of one heme ring requires eight molecules of glycine ,which contribute all four nitrogen atoms plus five carbon atoms.

2.   succinyl-CoA is an intermediate of the Krebs cycle,

Cards.title: Heme synthesis
Cards.content: Heme synthesis starts in mitochondria with the condensation of succinyl-CoA with the amino acid glycine, activated by pyridoxal phosphate. ALA synthase is the rate-limiting enzyme of heme synthesis.

Cards.title: Delta AminoLeuvlinic Acid (ALA)
Cards.content: This is first compound formed in  heme synthesis in the mitochondria by the condensation of glycine and Succinyl CoA

Cards.title: AminoLeuvlinate Synthase
Cards.content: Is the First Enzyme in heme Synthesis pathway  found in the mitochondria that catalysed the condensation of Glycine and Succinyl CoA to form ALA. It is referred to as a rate limiting enzyme of heme Synthesis because it is the key enzyme that begins heme Synthesis and it determines the overall rate of heme Synthesis

Cards.title: pyridoxal Phosphate
Cards.content: pyridoxal Phosphate is the active form of pyridoxine or vitamin B6. And also a Cofactor/Co-enzyme to ALA Synthase in the Synthesis of Delta AminoLeuvlinic acid.

Cards.title: Porphobilinogen (PBG)
Cards.content: This is the second compound formed in the heme synthetic pathway, four molecules of PBG are formed by the condensation and dehydration of two molecules of AminoLeuvlinic acid, and they are monopyrole

Cards.title: ALA Dehydratase
Cards.content: This is the second enzyme involved in heme synthesis, that catalysed the reaction of two molecules of ALA to form four pyrole i.e Porphobilinogen, it requires zinc for it's activity and can be inhibited by lead.

Cards.title: porphyrins
Cards.content: Porphyrins are cyclic molecules formed by the linkage of four pyrrole rings through methenyl bridges.

Cards.title: Heme structure 1
Cards.content: The heme structure contains a ring of tetrapyrrole. The tetrapyrrole is formed by joining four pyrrole rings. A pyrrole has four atoms of carbon and one atom of nitrogen arranged in the shape of a pentagon. If the tetrapyrrole contains a metal ion between its ring structure, this ring structure is known as porphyrin.

Cards.title: Uroporphyrinogen 3
Cards.content: This the 3rd significant compound formed in heme synthetic pathway and the first porphyrinogen to be formed in heme synthesis,  it contains four pyrole rings linked by a methenyl bridges (derived from alpha carbon of glycine) formed from four molecules of porphobilinogen.

Cards.title: Uroporphyrinogen 1 Synthase / Porphobilinogen deaminase
Cards.content: This is the 3rd enzyme in heme synthetic pathway that catalysed the condensation and deamination (in which four molecules of ammonia is removed) of four molecules of porphobilinogen to form hydroxymethylbilane

Cards.title: Hydroxymethylbilane
Cards.content: Is a linear tetrapyrrole that is formed from the condensation and deamination of four pyrole ring porphobilinogen and due to its unstablility it undergoes a spontaneous cyclization to form Uroporphyrinogen 1

Cards.title: Uroporphyrinogen 1 Synthase
Cards.content: This enzyme rearranged the orientation of propionate and vinyl group of one of the pyrole ring which ring number 4 of Uroporphyrinogen 1 to form Uroporphyrinogen 3

Cards.title: Coproporphyrinogen 3
Cards.content: This is the fifth compound form from the decarboxylation (total of 4 carbon iv oxide molecules) of Uroporphyrinogen 3 and it then diffused into the mitochondria from the cytosol

Cards.title: Protoporphrinogen ix
Cards.content: Is the formed from the oxidation of Coproporphyrinogen 3

Cards.title: Coproporphyrinogen oxidase
Cards.content: Oxidizes Coproporphyrinogen 3 to protoporphrinogen

Cards.title: Protoporphrinogen oxidase
Cards.content: Oxidizes protoporphrinogen ix to protoporphrin ix

Cards.title: Ferrochelatase
Cards.content: Oxides protoporphrin ix to heme

Cards.title: Axial & Appendicular Skeleton
Cards.content: axial skeleton, the part of the bony structure of the body that consists of the bones of the skull, the vertebral column, and the rib cage. The axial skeleton serves primarily to support and protect the heart, lungs, and central nervous system, which is made up of the brain and spinal cord. The axial skeleton differs from the appendicular skeleton, which is made up of the bones of the upper and lower limbs.

Cards.title: Pectoral Girdle
Cards.content: A pectoral girdle, also referred to as the shoulder girdle, connects your upper limbs to the bones along the axis of your body. You have two pectoral girdles in your body. The pectoral girdle consists of the two bones that make up your shoulder: clavicle, or collarbone. scapula, or shoulder blade.

Cards.title: Function of the clavicle
Cards.content:
It act as a strut that holds the upper limb far away from the trunk which allows free movement and rotation of the upper limb for various activities

 (2). It provides area for muscle attachments 

(3). It transmitts force from the upper limb to the axial skeleton sternum.

Cards.title: Parts of a Clavicle
Cards.content:
Medial end :-: the medial end is quadrilateral and it is attached to the sternum, 

lateral end :-: is flattened is attached to acomion of the scapular.

Shaft :-: is circular , two third of the shaft is convex white one third is concave and it has a groove located inferriory

Cards.title: Ossification
Cards.content:
Ossification: The process of creating bone, that is of transforming cartilage (or fibrous tissue) into bone. 
The process of bone formation is called osteogenesis or ossification. After progenitor cells form osteoblastic lines, they proceed with three stages of development of cell differentiation, called proliferation, maturation of matrix, and mineralization

Cards.title: Clavicle osification
Cards.content: Osification of clavicle is Membranocartilaginous, all the osifies of clavicle are membrane except the medial end which is cartilaginous, (this means that membrane and cartilage undergoes ossification to form the clavicle bone). And their four osification center, the two primary center for the shaft and two secondary center for each of the ends. Clavicle is the first bone to ossify in human body

Cards.title: Clavicle fracture
Cards.content: The site where normally got fractured in the clavicle when the shoulder experience a force is the junction of its lateral concave one third and medial convex two third. This is because that's the weakest site of the clavicle, and it is the site where the two curves join

Cards.title: Cleidocranial dysostosis
Cards.content:
Cleidocranial dysostosis: It is a clinical condition 
characterized by partial or complete absence of clavicle 
associated with defective ossification of the skull bones.

Cards.title: Clavicle dysostosis
Cards.content:
Clavicular dysostosis: It is a clinical condition in which 
medial and lateral parts of clavicle remain separate due to 
nonunion of two primary centers of ossification.

Cards.title: Definition and anatomical positions Scapular
Cards.content: It is a large, flattened and trianglar bone located on the upper part of the posterolateral aspect of the thorax against 2nd to 7th ribs

Cards.title: Parts of Scapular
Cards.content:
1). The surface(it has dorsal and costal surface)
2) border(lateral, medial,superior border) 
3) angle (superior, inferior and lateral)

Cards.title: Process in scapular
Cards.content:
1) Spinous process: a shell like projection at the posterior part of the scalpular or dorsal surface of the scapular. And it divides the dorsal surface into two third supraspinous fossa, and one third infraspinatus fossa.
2) coracoid process: that's where the clavicle bone articulate with the coracoid to form coracoclavicle joint
3) glenoid process: articulate with the ball like head of the humerus to form glenohumeral joint a ball and socket joint and a synovial joint.

Cards.title: infraspinatus muscle
Cards.content: Arrise from medial two third of the infraspinous fossa(bellow the spinous process)

Cards.title: Supraspinatus muscle
Cards.content: Arisea from two third of the supraspinous fossa (above the spine process)

Cards.title: spinoglenoid notch
Cards.content: Located between the border of the spinous process and the dorsal surface of the neck of the scapular through which the supraspinous fossa communicate with the infraspinous fossa, and through which the subscapular nerve pass from supraspinous fossa to infraspinous fossa

Cards.title: Scapular Osification
Cards.content:
The ossification of scapula is cartilaginous. The cartilaginous 
scapula is ossified by eight centres—one primary and seven 
secondary.
The primary centre appears in the body.
The secondary centres appear as follows:
1. Two centres appear in the coracoid process.
2. Two centres appear in the acromion process.
3. One centre appears each in the (a) medial border, 
(b) inferior angle, and (c) in the lower part of the rim of 
glenoid cavity.
The primary centre in the body and first secondary centre 
in the coracoid process appears in eighth week of 
intrauterine life (IUL) and first year of postnatal life, 
respectively and they fuse at the age of 15 years.
All other secondary centres appear at about puberty and 
fuse by 20th year.

Cards.title: Humerus
Cards.content: This bone of the arm, it is longest and strongest bone of the upper limb

Cards.title: Parts of the humerus
Cards.content:
1) the upper end
2) the lower end
3) shaft

Cards.content: Number System is the building blocks of computer and information technology.

Cards.content: To convert from any base to base ten, the place value method is used

Cards.title: Carbohydrates definition
Cards.content:
The word carbohydrate is a contraction of “hydrated carbon”.

optically active polyhydroxy aldehydes or ketones or the compounds which produce units of such type on hydrolysis.

The general formula for carbohydrates is Cx(H2O)y.

Carbohydrates are polyhydroxy aldehydes, ketones,

Cards.title: Types of Carbohydrates
Cards.content:
The three main types are
1. Monosaccharides (one sugar unit, they monomers of Carbohydrates)

2. Oligosaccharides( made up of 2 to 10 simple sugar units)

3. Polysaccharides (more than 10 sugar units)

Cards.title: D-glucose
Cards.content: It is also known as dextrose, because it is dextrorotatory (meaning that as an optical isomer is rotates plane polarized light to the right and also an origin for the D designation. Glucose is also called blood sugar as it circulates in the blood at a concentration of 65-110 mg/dL of blood

Cards.title: L-glucose
Cards.content:
L-glucose is a short form of Levorotatory-glucose. It is one of the two stereoisomers of glucose (the other is D-glucose). Compared with D-glucose, the L-glucose is less biologically active and less common. In higher forms of organisms, the L-glucose is not produced naturally.

An L-stereoisomer of glucose molecule, which is comparatively less biologically active than D-glucose, and one that rotates the plane polarized light in an anticlockwise direction (as opposed to D-glucose that rotates it in clockwise direction)

L-glucose cannot be used as a source of energy in cellular respiration. That is because hexokinase cannot phosphorylate it during glycolysis. Burkholderia caryophylli, though, has the enzyme D-threo-aldose 1-dehydrogenase that enables the oxidation of L-glucose.1

Cards.title: Steroisomers of Glucose
Cards.content:
Steroisomers of Glucose includ
1. D-glucose
2. L-glucose

Cards.title: Properties of monosaccharides
Cards.content:
1. Colorless
2. Crystalline solid
3. Soluble in water, and insoluble in non polar solvent,
4. They can be in open or ring chain form

Cards.title: Steroisomers
Cards.content:
Stereoisomers are molecules that share the same molecular formula and arrangement of atoms, but differ from one another in 3-dimensional space, or in their spatial arrangement 

And it is divide into optical isomer and geometric isomer

Optical is further divided into 
Enantiomers and Diastereomer

Cards.title: Enantiomers
Cards.content:
Enantiomers

Enantiomers are non-superimposable mirror images of each. Enantiomerism is shown by the chiral molecules. They have four different groups attached to the central chiral carbon. Enantiomers are asymmetrical molecules and have the tendency to rotate plane-polarized light in opposite directions.

Cards.title: Types of monosaccharides
Cards.content: Glucose, frutose, ribose, galactose, ribose

Cards.title: Haworth projection
Cards.content: Haworth projection formulae is a structural representation of cyclic structure of monosaccharides either in pyranose or furanose form.

Cards.title: Hemiacetal
Cards.content: A hemiacetal is forms when an aldehyde reacts with an alcohol.

Cards.title: Fischer projection
Cards.content: In chemistry, the Fischer projection, devised by Emil Fischer in 1891, is a two-dimensional representation of a three-dimensional organic molecule

Cards.title: How ring chain are formed from open chain
Cards.content: Ring chain (hawel projection) is formed from open chain by the nucleophilic addition reaction between aldehydes in carbon 1 and hydroxyl group in carbon 5, in which the oxygen in hydroxyl group interact with carbon atom in the aldehyde by giving it one of its lone pair electron, and hydrogen from the hydroxyl group is transferred to bind with in the carbonyl group, which however the in the formation of hemiacetal (if it is ketone it will form hemiketal).

Cards.title: Furanose & pyranoses
Cards.content: When monosaccharides form five sided ring chain it is called FURANOSE e.g frutose, ribose . when six sided ring chain is formed is called PYRANOSES e.g glucose, galactose

Cards.title: Diastereomeric anomers of Glucose
Cards.content:
They are
 alpha D-glucose :-: the hydroxyl group in the Carbon 1 and hydroxyl group on carbon 4 are on the same sides
Hence called alpha D-glucopyranose

Beta D-glucose :-: the hydroxyl group on carbon 1 and hydroxyl group on carbon 4 are on the same Opposite hence called
Beta-D-glucopyranose

Cards.title: Frutose
Cards.content: Frutose is a ketohexose, i.e it has a ketone group and 6 carbon atom, when it form it's Ring chain in which the ketone group in react with hydroxyl on carbon 5 forming hemiketal, a five sided ring is formed, hence called D-frutofuranose

Cards.title: Disaccharides
Cards.content:
Include
Sucrose, lactose(milk), maltose
Formed by the conservation of two monosaccharides forming O-glycosidic bond

Cards.title: Maltose
Cards.content:
Maltose is composed of two units of alpha D-glucose linked together through an alpha 1,4 glycosidic bond.

Hence it is called alpha-D-glucopyranosyl (1-4) alpha-D-glucopyranoside

Cards.title: Sucrose
Cards.content:
Is formed by the condensation with the release of water of alpha D-glucose and beta D-glucose form apha-beta 1,3 glycosidic bond

Hence called alpha D-glucopyranosyl (1-3) beta-D-fructofuranose

Cards.title: Lactose
Cards.content:
Is formed by the condensation of beta D-glucose and beta D-galactose forming 2 beta 1,4 glycosidic bond

Hence called beta D-galacpyranosyl (1-4) Beta D-glucopyranoside

Cards.title: Polysaccharides
Cards.content:
Structural polysaccharides are chitin and cellulose

Storage Polysaccharides are glycogen and starch

Cards.title: Monosaccharides
Cards.content:
Monosaccharides, also called simple sugars, are the simplest forms of sugar and the most basic units from which all carbohydrates are built.
They are usually colorless, water-soluble, and crystalline solids.

In biology and biochemistry, a monosaccharide is a simple sugar that constitutes the building blocks of a more complex form of sugars 

Monosaccharides are sugars that cannot be broken down by hydrolysis into other simpler sugars. Examples include glucose and fructose.

Cards.title: Cytoplasm & cytosol
Cards.content:
Cytoplasm is the liquid component of the cell which is all the contents of the cell except the nucleus. The cytosol is located in the cytoplasm and is made up of water, ions, molecules, and proteins. It contains various enzymes and biomolecules necessary for cell metabolism.

Cytosol is known as the matrix of the cytoplasm. It surrounds the cell organelles in eukaryotes. In prokaryotes, all the metabolic reactions occur here.

Cards.title: Chemical properties of Carbohydrates
Cards.content:
(1). Osazone Formation 
(2). Benedict test
(3). Oxidation

Cards.title: Osazone test
Cards.content: Osazone test is a chemical test used to detect reducing sugars. This test even allows the differentiation of different reducing sugars on the basis of the time of appearance of the complex. This test is also termed Phenyl hydrazine test based on the reagent used for this test.

Cards.title: Osazone
Cards.content: Osazone is an Oxidation product, and carbon 1&2 of aldose are required for reaction

Cards.title: Osazone Formation
Cards.content: Osazone Formation: The reaction between three moles of phenylhydrazine and one mole of aldose produces a crystalline product known as phenylosazone

Cards.title: Benedict test
Cards.content:
Benedict’s test is a chemical test that can be used to check for the presence of reducing sugars in a given analyte. Therefore, simple carbohydrates containing a free ketone or aldehyde functional group can be identified with this test. The test is based on Benedict’s reagent (also known as Benedict’s solution), which is a complex mixture of sodium citrate, sodium carbonate, and the pentahydrate of copper(II) sulfate.

When exposed to reducing sugars, the reactions undergone by Benedict’s reagent result in the formation of a brick-red precipitate, which indicates a positive Benedict’s test


When a reducing sugar is subjected to heat in the presence of an alkali, it gets converted into an enediol (which is a relatively powerful reducing agent). Therefore, when reducing sugars are present in the analyte, the cupric ions (Cu2+) in Benedict’s reagent are reduced to cuprous ions (Cu+). These cuprous ions form copper(I) oxide with the reaction mixture and precipitate out as a brick-red coloured compound.

Cards.title: Benedict Reagents
Cards.content: Benedict's reagent is a chemical reagent and complex mixture of sodium carbonate, sodium citrate, and copper(II) sulfate pentahydrate.

Cards.title: Oxidation of Carbohydrates
Cards.content: Carbohydrates are readily oxidized in presence of a reducing agent to form an acidic sugar (carboxylic acid) hence they called reducing sugar

Cards.title: Reduction of Carbohydrates
Cards.content: The carbonyl form of carbohydrates can be reduced to alcohol by a reducing agent sodium borohydride. It is a nucleophilic addition reaction where the C=O. group is reduced to alcohol by sodium borohydride. The resulting product is known as alditols. If the carbohydrate is an aldehyde, it is reduced to primary alcohol, but if it is a ketose, it forms secondary alcohol.

Cards.title: Parts of the humerus
Cards.content:
(1). The upper end.
(2). The shaft
(3). The lower end

Cards.title: The upper end
Cards.content:
(1). The head
(2). The neck
(3). The greater tubercle
(4). The lesser tubercle
(5). Intertubercular sulcus or bicipital groove

Cards.title: Lower end
Cards.content:
(1). Medial epicondyle
(2). Lateral epicondyle
(3). Capitulum
(4). Trochlea
(5). Radius fossa
(6). Coronoid fossa
(7). alecranon fossa

Cards.title: Shaft
Cards.content:
This longest part of the humerus extending between the upper and the lower end, it is cylindrical at the upper half and flattened at the lower half.

It has three border
(Anterior, media, lateral)

And three surface
(Anteromedial, Anterolateral, posterior)

Cards.title: Upper end :-: Head
Cards.content: It is rounded and it faced medially backwards and upwards, it is covered by hyaline cartilage

Cards.title: Upper end :-: Neck
Cards.content:
Humerus has three neck
(1). The anatomical neck :-: separates the head from the tubercle at the upper of the humerus and also it provides attachment to the capsule ligament of the shoulder joint.

(2). Surgical neck :-: it is below the tubercle of the upper end and it is the weaker part of the upper end of the humerus because it is at this side that most humerus fracture occur hence it is called surgical neck.

(3) morphological neck :-: it is the junction between the epiphysis and diaphysis of humerus and it is the true junction of the upper end and shaft of the humerus ,
It shows the position of the epiphyseal line

Cards.title: Upper end :-: Greater tubercle
Cards.content:
Is the most lateral part of the humerus, and it's posterosuperior part has three (upper, middle 
and lower)  flattened facet-like impression for the attachment of three muscle,  the supraspinous muscle, infraspinous muscle and the trees minor muscle (SIT) respectively.

Cards.title: Upper end:-: lesser tubercle
Cards.content: It's located medially at the upper end of the humerus, above the surgical neck. It provides attachment to the subscapularis muscle.

Cards.title: Intertubercular sulcus or bicipital groove
Cards.content:
This is a vertical groove that is between the two tubercle. 
It contains
1. The long head of the biceps enclosed in a synovial sheath
2. The branch of ascending posterior circumflex humeral artery

Three muscle are attached to the following part of the intertubercular sulcus

1. Pectoralis major on the lateral lip of the groove
2. Teres major on the medial lip of the groove
3. Latissimus Dorsi on the floor of the groove 

A lady between two major

Cards.title: Breast: description
Cards.content: The breast is a superficial, conspicuous and prominent located on the anterior thoracic wall. It extends horizontally from the lateral border of the sternum to the mid-axillary line. Vertically, it spans between the 2nd and 6th costal cartilages. It lies superficially to the pectoralis major and serratus anterior muscles.

Cards.title: Breast: outline
Cards.content:
:> Description & location
:> related structure 
:> structure
:> skin
:> stroma
:> parenchyma
:> Arterial Supply
:> Venous drainage
:> Nerve supply
:> lymphatic nodes
:> lymphatic Drainage
:> Clinical correlation

Cards.title: Structure of the breast
Cards.content:
The can be structurally divided into
1. Skin
2. Stroma
3. Parenchyma

Cards.title: Skin
Cards.content:
This is the superficial coverings of the breast and it contains the following features
1.nipple
2. Areola

Cards.title: Skin :-' nipple
Cards.content: 1. Nipple:-: this a conical projection bellow the center of the breast and normally located at the 4th intercostal space. It contains smooth muscle fibres that makes it stiff, erect or flattened. It is innervated by sensory nerve endings hence it is the most sensitive part of the breast and event get erected during sexual arousal

Cards.title: Skin:-: areola
Cards.content: This is a circular pigmented skin located at the base of the nipple, it contains a lot of modified sebaceous glands that secrets oily secretions that lubricate the nipple and the areola, during pregnancy this sebaceous glands enlarged to form MONTGOMERY'S TUBERCULES

Cards.title: Stroma
Cards.content:
The stroma consist of fatt and connective tissues, and it forms the supporting framework of the breast, 
Fat give the breast it's soft and succulent nature
The connective tissues condensed to form fibers strands called the suspensory ligament of cooper, they are arranged in a radial fashion, they connect the demis of the overlying skin to the duck of the breast and the pectoral facial, they maintain the protuberance and firmness of the breast.

Cards.title: Parenchyma
Cards.content: Parenchyma contains the mammary gland which is about 15 to 20 arranged in radial fashion and converges at the nipple it secrets milk that feeds a new born baby. Each gland is drained by a duck called lactiferous duct, near its termination each ducts expand into lactiferous sinus which serves as a temporal reservoir of milk during lactation.

Cards.title: Artery supply
Cards.content:
The breast are supplied oxygenated blood by the following artery

1. Internal thoracic artery or internal mammary artery through it's branches which pierced through the second , third and fourth intercostal spaces

2. Axillary artery which supply blood through it's branches which are, acromothoraxic artery, superior thoracic artery and lateral thoracic artery .

3. Posterior intercostal artery

Cards.title: Venous drainage
Cards.content:
This is carried out by the following vein
1. Axillary vein
2. Posterior intercostal vein 
3. Internal thoracic vein

Cards.title: Nerve Supply
Cards.content:
Nerve Supply is primary somatosensory. They are derived from the 2nd to 6th intercostal nerve through the lateral and anterior cutaneous branch. 

The sensory nerve at the areola and the nipple play an important role in stimulating the secretion of milk in response to suckling by infant.
The secretion of milk is done by a hormone called prolactin secreted by pituitary gland.

Cards.title: Lymp
Cards.content: Lymp

Cards.title: Lymphatic Drainage
Cards.content:
(lymph are basically fluids that comes out of the capillaries of the artery during materials exchange with the cell of the breast) 
These lymph are drained in to the following lymph groups if nodes

1. Axillary lymph nodes ( and is divided into five lymph node 
(i). Lateral or humeral axillary lymph nodes
(ii). Anterior (pectoral)
(iii). posterior (subscapular)
(iv). central
(v). apical nodes. The apical nodes are the final common pathway for all of the axillary lymph nodes. )

2. Internal mammary nodes [lying along the internal thoracic vessels]

3. Supraclavicular node [ lying above the clavicle]

4. Posterior intercostal Nodes [ lying in the posterior part of the intercostal spaces in front of the head of the ribs]

5. Cephalic (deltopectorial ) nodes [lying in the deltopectorial groove]

Cards.title: Axilla
Cards.content: The axilla is an anatomical region under the shoulder joint where the arm connects to the shoulder. It contains a variety of neurovascular structures, including the axillary artery, axillary vein, brachial plexus, and lymph nodes.

Cards.title: Part of breast lymphatic Drainage
Cards.content:
Lymphatic Drainage is divided into two
1. Superficial drainage which drains the skin except the nipple and the areola
2. Deep drainage: drains the parenchyma of the breast including the nipple and the areola of the breast

Cards.title: Plexus
Cards.content: In neuroanatomy, a plexus is a branching network of vessels or nerves. The vessels may be blood vessels (veins, capillaries) or lymphatic vessels.

Cards.title: Sappey plexus
Cards.content: The lymp that drain deep of the areola are called subareolar plexus of sappey and they drain into the anterior group of the axillary node.

Cards.title: Method of drainage
Cards.content:
1. Most lymph from the lateral quadrant of the breast drain into the anterior axillary nodes
2. Most from the medial quadrant drain into the internal mammary nodes
3. Few from lower lateral quadrant drains into the posterior intercostal Nodes
4. Few from lower medial quadrant drains into subdiaphragmatic and subpectoneal lymph plexus

Cards.title: Membrane potential
Cards.content:
Membrane potential (also transmembrane potential or membrane voltage) is the difference in electric potential between the interior and the exterior of a cell

Membrane potential is a potential gradient that forces ions to passively move in one direction: positive ions are attracted by the 'negative' side of the membrane and negative ions by the 'positive' one.

Membrane potentials in cells are determined primarily by three factors: 1) the concentration of ions on the inside and outside of the cell; 2) the permeability of the cell membrane to those ions (i.e., ion conductance) through specific ion channels; and 3) by the activity of electrogenic pumps (e.g., Na+/K+-ATPase and Ca++ transport pump

Cards.title: Resting membrane potential
Cards.content:
This is the relatively stable and ground value of the membrane or transmembrane voltage/potential of an unexcited or resting cells 

Or
The resting membrane potential (RMP) is the electrical potential difference across the plasma membrane of a cell when the cell is at rest

Cards.title: Sodium concentration
Cards.content: Na+ is a positively charged ion that has an intracellular concentration of 14 mM, an extracellular concentration of 140 mM, and an equilibrium potential value of +65 mV.

Cards.title: Factors that determine the membrane potential
Cards.content:
1. The concentration of ions in and out of the cell,

2. The activity of the electrogenic pump e.g Na+/K+ ATPase and Ca+ transport pump which maintains the concentration of ions across the membrane .

3. Permeability of cell membrane to ions(Na+, K+, Ca+) through specific channels

4. The presence of fixed and non-diffusable Negatively charged protein Molecules.

Cards.title: Voltage Clamp
Cards.content:
The voltage clamp is an experimental method used by electrophysiologists to measure the ion currents through the membranes of excitable cells, such as neurons, while holding the membrane voltage at a set level.[1] A basic voltage clamp will iteratively measure the membrane potential, and then change the membrane potential (voltage) to a desired value by adding the necessary current. This "clamps" the cell membrane at a desired constant voltage, allowing the voltage clamp to record what currents are delivered. Because the currents applied to the cell must be equal to (and opposite in charge to) the current going across the cell membrane at the set voltage, the recorded currents indicate how the cell reacts to changes in membrane potential.[2] Cell membranes of excitable cells contain many different kinds of ion channels, some of which are voltage-gated. The voltage clamp allows the membrane voltage to be manipulated independently of the ionic currents, allowing the current–voltage relationships of membrane channels to be studied.[3]

The voltage clamp operates by negative feedback. The membrane potential amplifier measures membrane voltage and sends output to the feedback amplifier; this subtracts the membrane voltage from the command voltage, which it receives from the signal generator. This signal is amplified and output is sent into the axon via the current-passing electrode.

Cards.title: Na+/K+ ATPase
Cards.content:
Na+/K+-pump is an electrogenic transmembrane ATPase located in the outer plasma membrane of cells. The Na+/K+-ATPase pumps 3 sodium ions out of cells while pumping 2 potassium ions into cells.

The sodium–potassium pump is found in many cell (plasma) membranes. Powered by ATP, the pump moves sodium and potassium ions in opposite directions, each against its concentration gradient. In a single cycle of the pump, three sodium ions are extruded from and two potassium ions are imported into the cell.

Cards.title: Function of Na+/K+ pump
Cards.content:
1. The Na+K+-ATPase pump helps to maintain osmotic equilibrium and membrane potential in cells.

2.  The sodium and potassium move against the concentration gradients.

3.  The Na+ K+-ATPase pump maintains the gradient of a higher concentration of sodium extracellularly and a higher level of potassium intracellularly.

5.:Maintenance of resting membrane potential (across the neuronal membrane).

6. Absorption of glucose from the gut and renal tubules (symport).

7. Maintenance of cellular osmolarity.

Cards.title: Cathode Ray oscilloscope
Cards.content:
The cathode-ray oscilloscope (CRO) is a common laboratory instrument that provides accurate time and aplitude measurements of voltage signals over a wide range of frequencies

a CRO is a device that is used for measuring and displaying different forms of electrical signals.

Cards.title: RMP measurements
Cards.content:
The resting potential of a cell can be measured using a device called, cathode Ray oscilloscope
The value of the RMP is about -65mv to -85mv

RMP can be measured using the intracellular recording method, which involves the use of two microelectrode, the recording electrode  penetrates inside the cell, while the reference electrode is placed outsider the cell, and it now connected to a voltameter

Cards.content:

Cards.title: Ionic base of RMP
Cards.content:
RMP of cell is achieved by the following process

1. The activity of the Na+/K+ ATPase which pump out 3Na+ and pump in 2K+ simultaneously. Due to the unequal movement of ion across the membrane creates a deficit positive charge inside the cell generating a voltage of about -4mv, and it also create a concentration gradient of ions across the cell membrane.

2. Due to the activity of the Na+/K+ pump the conc of K+ becomes higher intracellularly hence K+ will tend to move out of the cell through the leaky K+ channel along its concentration gradient leaving behind negative protein increasing the negativity of the intracellular to about -90mv

3. Na+ being highly concentrated outside move into the cell through the leaky Na+ ion channel a long it concentration gradient hence reducing the negativity of the cell intracellular fluid to about -86mv
Hence summing it up give a RMP of -70mv.

Cards.title: Diaphysis & Epiphysis
Cards.content:
The diaphysis ( PL : diaphyses) is the main or midsection (shaft) of a long bone. It is made up of cortical bone and usually contains bone marrow and adipose 

The epiphysis is the expanded or rounded end portion of a long bone. It has red bone marrow-producing erythrocytes

The junction between the epiphysis and diaphysis of humerus is called morphological neck

Cards.title: Shaft:-: Anterior Border
Cards.content:
Shaft of Humerus has three border

1. Anterior border:-: extends from the lateral lib of the intertubercular sulcus through the anterior margin of the deltoid tuberosity where it becomes smooth and rounded
Down to the radial fossa.

Cards.title: Shaft :-: Medial border
Cards.content:
Medial border provide attachment to three muscle. 
[ medial intermuscular septum, coracobrachialis, pronator teres]

2. Medial Border :-: extends from the medial lib of  intertubercular sulcus to the medial epicondyle,

The lower part of this border is sharp and is called medial supracondylar ridge which provides attachment to medial intermuscular septum 

The middle of the border has a rough strip which provides attachment to coracobrachialis muscle.

Above the medial epicondyle theirs a narrow area that provides origin to the head of Humerus of pronator teres

Cards.title: Shaft :-: lateral border
Cards.content:
The lower part of the Lateral border forms the lateral supracondylar ridge which provides attachment to lateral intermuscular septum.

Above the lateral supracondylar ridge is ill defined but traceable to the posterior part of the greater tubercle.

Cards.title: Shaft :-: AnteriorLateral Surface
Cards.content: Lies between the Anterior border and the lateral border, little bit above the middle of the border is a v-shaped tuberosity called deltoid tuberosity which provides attachment to deltoid muscle

Cards.title: Shaft :-: Anteriormedial surface
Cards.content: Lies between the Anterior border and medial border, upper part of the surface is the floor of the intertubercular sulcus. Above the middle near the medial border is a nutrient foramen directed downwards

Cards.title: Shaft :-: posterior surface
Cards.content:
Lies between the medial border and the lateral border, upper one third of the surface is an obligue rigde directed downwards and laterally, it provide attachment to the lateral head of tricep brachai.
It's middle one third is crossed by radial groove which relates with the radial nerve

Cards.title: Lower End
Cards.content:
The lower end of the humerus is flattened posteriorly and anteriorly but expanded side by side.
Is divided into 7 parts

1. Capitulum :-: a rounded convex projection laterally, it articulate with the head of radius.

2. Trochlea :-: a pulley shaped projection medially, it articulate with the trochlear notch of ulna.

3. Ulnar Nerve :-: lies on the posterior surface of the medial epicondyle 

4. Medial epicondyle :-: it is a bony projection on the medial side of the lower end of humerus, its anterior surface is a common flexor origin to the superficial flexors of the forearm

5. Anteriolateral part of Lateral epicondyle :-: is a bony projection small than the medial epicondyle on the lateral side of the lower end of the humerus, 
The superficial extensor muscles have their common origin on the AnteriorLateral part of the lateral epicondyle.

6. Posterior part of lateral epicondyle provides are for the origin of anconeus muscle

7. Coronoid fossa :-: it is above anterior aspect the trochlea, it accommodate the coronoid process of ulna during flexion of the elbow.

8. Radial fossa :-: it is a depression above the anterior aspect of the capitulum that accommodate the head of radius when the elbow is flexed 

9. Alecranon fossa (latin ulna head) :-: it is a depression above the posterior aspect of the trochlea that accommodate the alecranon process of ulna when the elbow is extended.

Cards.title: Steroisomerism of Amino acid
Cards.content:
All amino acids except for glycine are stereoisomers. This means that there are mirror images of their structure. It is just like how we have left hands and right hands. These are labeled L (left-handed) and D (right-handed) to distinguish the mirror images.

Building blocks of proteins. Only L-amino acids are polymerized to form proteins, though both D-amino acids and non-L-amino acids found in nature.

Stereoisomers are designated D (dextro-rotatory) or L (levo-rotatory) according to the direction in which the crystalline forms rotate polarized light, to the ...

Cards.title: Threonine
Cards.content: Threonine has two chiral centers and therefore four possible stereoisomers. The isomers other than Thr (D-, L-allo-, and D-allo-threonine) are rare in nature and have no value, nutritional or otherwise. These days, most Thr is synthesized rather than being obtained from natural proteins.

Cards.title: Optical activity
Cards.content:
Except glycine, all amino acids have asymmetric (chiral) carbon so they are optically active. Some amino acids are dextrorotatory and some levo rotatory depending upon the rotation of plane polarized light towards right or left direction respectively.

The optical activity of proteins is due to two factors — the asymmetry of the polypeptide chain and the asymmetry at the α-carbon atoms in the amino acid residues.

Cards.title: Standard amino acid
Cards.content: Amino acids typically are classified as standard or nonstandard, based on the polarity, or distribution of electric charge, of the R group (side chain). The 20 (or 21) amino acids that function as building blocks of proteins are classified as standard.

Cards.title: Function of protein
Cards.content:
1. Act as an enzyme [ e.g lipase (which is found in the duodenum that covert lipid to fatty acid and glycerol),  Maltese(convert maltase to glucose) etc. ]

2. Chemical signalling (hormone. Insulin, glucagon, thyrocalcitonin, pituitary hormones, and hypothalamic hormones are examples of protein hormones. They are also known as polypeptide hormones.)

3. Storage functions (
Sure thing! Some examples of storage proteins include ferritin, casein, and ovalbumin. Ferritin stores iron in our body, while casein is a protein found in milk that serves as a source of amino acids for newborns. Ovalbumin, on the other hand, is a protein found in egg whites that provides nutrients for the developing embryo. These proteins are like little storage units for important substances!)

5. Protection (Antibodies
Some examples of proteins that are antibodies include immunoglobulin G (IgG), immunoglobulin A (IgA), immunoglobulin M (IgM), and immunoglobulin E (IgE). They play a crucial role in our immune response! 

For example, IgG, the most common antibody, is present mostly in the blood and tissue fluids, while IgA is found in the mucous membranes lining the respiratory and gastrointestinal tracts.
)

6. Contractile function (myosin)

7. Structural (Collagen is the main structural protein in the extracellular matrix. found throughout the body, particularly in skin, bones, ligaments, tendons, teeth, and connective tissues. As the main component of connective tissue, it is the most abundant protein in mammals, making up from 25% to 35% of the whole-body..)

8. Transport (hemoglobin)

Cards.title: Peptides bond
Cards.content:
A peptide bond, also called an eupeptide bond, is a chemical bond that is formed by joining the carboxyl group of one amino acid to the amino group of another.

During the formation of this bond, there is a release of water (H2O) molecules ( hydrogen from alpha amino group and hydroxyl moiety from carboxyl group. A peptide bond is usually a covalent bond (CO-NH bond), and since the water molecule is eliminated, it is considered a dehydration process

Peptide is a Greek word that means “digested”. A peptide is a short polymer of amino acid monomers linked by an amide bond.

Cards.title: Characteristics of peptides bond
Cards.content:
. Peptide bonds are strong with partial double bond character:

They are not broken by heating or high salt concentration.
They can be broken by exposing them to strong acids or bases for a long time at elevated temperature, and also by some specific enzymes (digestive enzymes).
2. Peptide bonds are rigid and planar bonds; therefore, they stabilise protein structure.

3. Peptide bond contains partial positive charge groups (polar hydrogen atoms of amino groups) and partial negative charge groups (polar oxygen atoms of carboxyl groups).

Cards.title: Form of amino acid
Cards.content:
Dipeptide = contains 2 amino acid units.

Tripeptide = contains 3 amino acid units.

Tetrapeptide = contains 4 amino acid units.

Oligopeptide = contains not more than 10 amino acid units.

Polypeptide = contains more than 10 amino acid units, up to 100 residues.

Macropeptides = made up of more than 100 amino acids

Cards.title: Degradation of peptides bond
Cards.content: The degradation of peptide bonds involves a reaction in which the breaking of the peptide bonds between the molecules occurs. Hydrolysis (addition of water) is the reaction used for the degradation of the peptide bond. During the reaction, they will emit Gibbs energy in an amount of 8-16 kJ/mol. But generally, this is a very slow process having a half-life of 350 to 600 years per bond at a temperature of 25oC. Enzymes like proteases are used as the catalysts for this process.

Cards.title: Peptides bond structure
Cards.content:
A peptide bond is a planar, trans and rigid configuration. It also shows a partial double bond character. The coplanarity of the peptide bond denotes the resonance or partial sharing of two pairs of electrons between the amide nitrogen and carboxyl oxygen.

The atoms C, H, N, and O of the peptide bond lie in the same plane, like the hydrogen atom of the amide group and the oxygen atom of the carboxyl group, which are trans to each other.

Linus Pauling and Robert Corey are the scientists who found that the peptide bonds are rigid and planar.

Cards.content:

Cards.title: Primary Structure of Protein
Cards.content:
This is the Simplest level of protein structure which is a linear sequence of amino acid linked through the formation of a peptide bond(a condensation /dehydration reaction) to form a polypeptides. Conventionally it begins with an amino-terminal end to a carboxylic terminal end.

However the sequence at which these amino acid are linked is determined by the DNA that encoded the protein hence the structure and function of the protein is determined by the sequence.

Cards.title: Sickle cell anemia
Cards.content:
Hemoglobin which is a protein pigment of the RBC that transport oxygen in the body, it's molecules is made of two alpha chain and two Beta chains of polypeptides, each of these subunits is made of 150 amino acid, total of 600,

When the glutamic amino acid , a sixth amino acid in the Beta chains is replaced by valine amino acid it's affect the structure and function of the protein, it distort the disc-shaped structure of the blood to crescent shape forming "sickle RBC" which prevents a normal flow through the blood vessels causing SICKLE CELL ANEMIA

Cards.title: Secondary Structure
Cards.content: This a local, repeating folded structure of polypeptides long chain, which is due to the interaction between the Carboxyl group and the amine group of the peptide bonds stabilized by hydrogen bond

Cards.title: Secondary Structure:-: Alpha helix
Cards.content: In an α helix, the carbonyl (C=O) of one amino acid is hydrogen bonded to the amino H (N-H) of an amino acid that is four down the chain. (E.g., the carbonyl of amino acid 1 would form a hydrogen bond to the N-H of amino acid 5.) This pattern of bonding pulls the polypeptide chain into a helical structure that resembles a curled ribbon, with each turn of the helix containing 3.6 amino acids. The R groups of the amino acids stick outward from the α helix, where they are free to interact.

Cards.title: Beta pleated sheet
Cards.content:
In this arrangement, the polypeptide chains are stretched out beside one another and then bonded by intermolecular H-bonds

In a β pleated sheet, two or more segments of a polypeptide chain line up next to each other, forming a sheet-like structure held together by hydrogen bonds. The hydrogen bonds form between carbonyl and amino groups of backbone, while the R groups extend above and below the plane of the sheet
3
3
 cubed. The strands of a β pleated sheet may be parallel, pointing in the same direction (meaning that their N- and C-termini match up), or antiparallel, pointing in opposite directions (meaning that the N-terminus of one strand is positioned next to the C-terminus of the other).

Cards.title: Hydrolysis of peptides bond
Cards.content:
Hydrolysis of peptides bond is simply the breaking of the bond by the addition of water molecules, this can only be done under the following conditions
1. Using a strong acid and base
2. Elevated temperature
3. Apply the above over a long period of time
4. This bone can be broken using a specific enzyme

Cards.title: Characteristics of peptides bond
Cards.content:
1. It's a partial double bond characters because the bond distance between Carbon from the Carboxyl group and Nitrogen from the amino group is 1.32 Angstroms which is lower than single bond distance between C-N which is 1.4g Angrostrom and more than the double bond distance between C-N which is 1.27g Angrostrom hence it is neither single or double bond

2. It is rigid and planar

3. Rotation about the bond is not possible because of it's rigidity

4. Trans-configuration, this means that the R side Chain of the two condensing amino acid residue is on the opposite to each other about the peptide bond

Cards.title: Tertiary Structure
Cards.content:
Protein tertiary structure is the three dimensional shape of a protein. The tertiary structure will have a single polypeptide chain "backbone" with one or more protein secondary structures, 

The tertiary structure of a protein refers to the overall three-dimensional arrangement of its polypeptide chain in space. It is generally stabilized by 
1.outside polar hydrophilic hydrogen and
2.  ionic bond interactions, and internal hydrophobic interactions between nonpolar amino acid side chains

The tertiary structure is the structure at which polypeptide chains become functionalThe tertiary structure is the structure at which polypeptide chains become functional. At this level, every protein has a specific three-dimensional shape and presents functional groups on its outer surface, allowing it to interact with other molecules, and giving it its unique function.

Cards.title: Tertiary:  Stabilizing force
Cards.content:
They of two types of force that stabilize the tertiary structure of protein
1. Covalent [ disulphide bond ]
2. Non-covalent [ 
 a. hydrogen bond, 
 b. hydrophobic interaction and 
 c.  ionic/electrostatic bond
 ]

Cards.content:
This occur between two SH ( sulfhydryl group) found in the side chain of Sulphur amino acid e.g cysteine amino acid

In the formation of this bond hydrogen atom from each SH group of the two amino acid side chain are displaced while the Surphur combined together 

Significance of This disulphide bond
1.  It prevents Denaturation of the protein and it moves to extracellular fluid of the cell for functional purposes

Cards.title: Tertiary: protein Disulphide Isomerase
Cards.content: Protein disulfide isomerase, or PDI, is an enzyme in the endoplasmic reticulum in eukaryotes and the periplasm of bacteria that catalyzes the formation and breakage of disulfide bonds between cysteine residues within proteins as they fold

In the body this hydrophobic side chain are always In close proximity due to the polar environment. Hence they interact with one another. This also helps in the stabilization of the tertiary structure .

Cards.title: Tertiary: ionic bond
Cards.content: This is between positively charge amino acid side chain e.g Lysine & Arginine and electronegative side chain of amino acids e.g Aspartate & Glutamate

Cards.title: Significance of tertiary structure
Cards.content:
Tertiary Structure is the structure at which a proteins becomes functional, 
Hence it is essential for the biological activity of protein

E.g in Ribonuclease an enzyme has two Histidine located at the 12th and 119th position of amino acid sequence, although they far from each other due to the 3D folding (tertiary structure) of the enzyme they were able to come together to form the active site of the enzyme.

Cards.title: Domain
Cards.content:
Domains are the structural, functional or evolutionary units of proteins. Proteins can comprise a single domain or a combination of domains. In multi-domain proteins, the domains almost always occur end-to-end, i.e., one domain follows the C-terminal end of another domainIn the three-dimensional structure of proteins,

 domains are stably folded structural units that retain molecular function independent of the rest of the larger

Each domain can contain maximum of 300 amino acid and minimum of 25 amino acid

Cards.title: Quaternary structure
Cards.content:
The quaternary structure of a protein is the association of several protein chains or subunits into a closely packed arrangement

Quaternary protein structure, on the other hand, refers to the arrangement of multiple polypeptide chains, or subunits, in a protein complex. In quaternary structure, each subunit may have its own tertiary structure, and the subunits interact with each other through non-covalent bonds to form a stable protein complex.

Quaternary structure exists in proteins consisting of two or more identical or different polypeptide chains (subunits). These proteins are called oligomers because they have two or more subunits. The quaternary structure describes the manner in which subunits are arranged in the native protein.

Tertiary structure is the overall 3D structure of the protein. Quaternary structure is the overall structure that arises when separate protein chains aggregate with self to form homodimers, homotrimers, or homopolymers OR aggregate with different proteins to form heteropolymers

Examples of proteins with quaternary structure include hemoglobin, DNA polymerase, ribosomes, antibodies, and ion channels.

Cards.title: Quaternary: Stabilizing force
Cards.content:
Quaternary structure describes the partial relationship between the subunits of protein through the following non-covalent bond

2. Hydrophobic interaction

Cards.content:
Homomeric protein: this the quatinary structure of protein with identical subunits e.g LDH5 lactate Dehydratase five subtype  isoenzyme which has 4 identical M chain

2. Heteromeric :-: has different/non-identical subunits e.g hemoglobin

Cards.title: Quaternary:-: Cooperativity
Cards.content: For example, when an oxygen atom binds to one of hemoglobin's four binding sites, the affinity to oxygen of the three remaining available binding sites increases; i.e. oxygen is more likely to bind to a hemoglobin bound to one oxygen than to an unbound hemoglobin. This is referred to as cooperative binding.

Cards.title: Quaternary structure Significance
Cards.content:
The tertiary structure gives proteins a very specific shape and is an important feature in the lock and key function of enzymes on the cell membrane. The quaternary structure of protein allows a protein to have multiple functions. They allow the protein to undergo conformational changes.

Quaternary structure may be defined as the specific association of subunits to form a single functional molecule. The arrangement of the subunits (monomers)

Cards.title: Casein
Cards.content:
Casein protein provides the body with all of the amino acids necessary to help build muscle. Casein protein is digested more slowly than other proteins, so it might be better at reducing appetite and increasing feelings of fullness.

Casein is a family of related phosphoproteins that are commonly found in mammalian milk, comprising about 80% of the proteins in cow's milk and between 20% and 60% of the proteins in human milk

Cards.title: Forearm
Cards.content: The forearm is the region of the upper limb between the elbow and the wrist. The term forearm is used in anatomy to distinguish it from the arm

Cards.title: Flexor
Cards.content:
flexor muscle, any of the muscles that decrease the angle between bones on two sides of a joint, as in bending the elbow or knee. Several of the muscles of the hands and feet are named for this function.

A flexor is a muscle that flexes a joint. In anatomy, flexion (from the Latin verb flectere, to bend) is a joint movement that decreases the angle between the bones that converge at the joint. For example, one's elbow joint flexes when one brings their hand closer to the shoulder.

Cards.title: Anconeus muscle
Cards.content:
The anconeus is a small muscle located at the elbow attaching the humerus and ulna. Although the anconeus muscle is active during elbow extension the importance of the anconeus for the movement itself is probably very small. The Triceps brachii muscle is by far the major muscle responsible for elbow extension.

Anconeus originates on the posterior surface of the lateral epicondyle of the humerus and inserts distally on the superior posterior surface of the ulna and the lateral aspect of the olecranon.

Cards.title: Diaphysis & epiphysis
Cards.content: The main difference between epiphysis and diaphysis is that epiphysis is the rounded end of a long bone, at its joint with adjacent bone(s), whereas diaphysis is the main or midsection (shaft) of a long bone. Furthermore, epiphysis is made up of spongy bone while diaphysis is made up of cortical bone.

Cards.title: Epiphyseal plate & line
Cards.content:
What is the difference between an epiphyseal plate and an epiphyseal line? The Epiphyseal plate contains cartilage used for producing bone. The Epiphyseal line is formed after the epiphyseal plate has stopped producing bone).

The growth plate, also known as the epiphyseal plate is a thin layer of cartilage that lies between the epiphyses and metaphyses, and is where the growth of long bones takes place.

Cards.title: Osification
Cards.content:
Humerus ossifies from one primary center and seven secondary center

Shaft :-: the primary center appear on the 8th week of development at the diaphysis (shaft)

Upper end :-: ossifies from three ossification secondary center, 
One for
1. Head (first year)
2. Greater tubercle (second year)
3. Lesser tubercle (fourth year)
The three fuses together on the sixth year the form a compound Epiphysis which fuses with the shaft on the 20th year

Lower end :-: ossifies from four secondary center one for

1. Capitulum and lateral flange of trochlea (first year)
2. Media flange of trochlea (9th year)
3. Lateral epicondyle (12th year)
The three fuses together to form another compound Epiphysis on the 14th year which fuses with the shaft on the 16 tear

4. Media epicondyle :-: ossifies from one secondary center on 4th-5th year to form a separate epicondyle which fuses with shaft on the 20th year

Cards.title: Occulation
Cards.content: An occlusion is a complete or partial blockage of a blood vessel. While occlusions can happen in both veins and arteries, the more serious ones occur in the arteries. An occlusion can reduce or even stop the flow of oxygen-rich blood to downstream vital tissues like the heart, brain, or extremities

Cards.title: Median nerve
Cards.content: What is the median nerve? The median nerve is a sensory and motor nerve of the arm (or upper limb). It arises from the lateral and medial cords of the brachial plexus, originating in the spinal cord, and runs through the anterior portion of the arm and forearm before finishing its path at the hand and digits (fingers).

Cards.title: Volkmann’s ischaemic contracture
Cards.content:
A Volkmann's contracture is a deformity of the hand, fingers, and wrist which occurs as a result of a trauma such as fractures, crush injuries, burns and arterial injuries. Following this trauma, there is a deficit in the arterio-venous circulation in the forearm which causes a decreased blood flow and hypoxia can lead to the damage of muscles, nerves and vascular endothelium. This results in a shortening (contracture) of the muscles in the forearm

A fracture of the supracondylary space causes a deficit in the circulation of the arteria brachialis. It is caused by the blocking of the circulation and a deficit in blood supply to the muscles and nerves malfunction. There is a contracture of the muscles, usually, the flexors of the wrist. Yet, there is also a contracture occurring with the extensors of the wrist, but this is less common.

Cards.title: Brachailis
Cards.content: The brachialis is an important flexor muscle of the forearm at the elbow. [1] The brachialis provides flexion of the elbow at all physiologic positions and is considered a "pure flexor" of the forearm at the elbow. [2] It lies in the anteroinferior area of the arm and is deeper than the biceps brachialis muscle.

Cards.title: Definition of cell
Cards.content:
Cells are the structural, functional, and biological units of all living beings.
It is a membrane bounded microscopic structure whose membrane is made up of two layers of phospholipids with embedded proteins. It separates the contents of the cell from its outside environment, as well as regulates what enters and exits the cell.

A cell consists of three parts: the cell membrane, the nucleus, and, between the two, the cytoplasm. Within the cytoplasm lie intricate arrangements of fine fibers and hundreds or even thousands of miniscule but distinct structures called organelles.

Cards.title: Rhombic Muscle
Cards.content:
The rhomboids are two bilateral, superficial muscles located in the upper back. They consist of two functionally similar muscles called rhomboid minor and rhomboid major. Together with trapezius, levator scapulae and latissimus dorsi, they comprise the superficial layer of the extrinsic back muscles.

The rhomboid muscles originate from  the nuchal ligament and the spinous processes of T2 to T5 vertebra and inserted to the medial border of the scapular adjacent to the scapular spine.

 Under innervation from the dorsal scapular nerve, the rhomboids primarily 
1. retract the scapula superomedially and 
2. rotate the glenoid cavity. 
3. the rhomboids are important to stabilize the scapula into position and reinforce the shoulder.

Cards.title: Levator Scapulae
Cards.content:
ORIGINATION 
The levator scapulae originates on the posterior tubercle of transverse process of cervical vertebrae 1 to 4

INSERTION 
The levator scapulae inserts on to the vertebral margin of the scapula between the superior angle and the root of the spine

FUNCTION 
The levator scapulae functions to elevate the scapula and tilt the glenoid cavity inferiorly by rotating the scapula downward.

POSITIONS
The superior third of the strap-like levator scapulae lies deep to the sternocleidomastoid while the inferior third is deep to the trapezius. From the transverse processes of the upper cervical vertebrae, the fibers of the levator of the scapula pass inferiorly to the superomedial border of the scapula

Cards.title: Serratus anterior
Cards.content:
anterior (SA) is a fan-shaped muscle that originates on the superolateral surfaces of the first to eighth or ninth ribs at the lateral wall of the thorax and inserts along the superior angle, medial border, and inferior angle of the scapula.

It is inserted at the medial border of the scapular on it's costal surface (costal surface is the anterior surface of the scapular that lies against the rib cage)


It acts on the scapula and is the prime mover in both scapular protraction and scapular upward rotation.
Is a key scapular stabilizer, keeping the shoulder blades against the ribcage when at rest and during movement.

The serratus anterior acts to pull the scapula forward around the thorax. The left side of the thorax. protracts and stabilizes scapula, assists in upward rotation. The muscle is named from Latin: serrare = to saw (referring to the shape); and anterior = on the front side of the body.

Cards.title: Supraspinatus
Cards.content:
Supraspinatus is one of the rotator cuff muscles, along with infraspinatus, teres minor and subscapularis muscles. Supraspinatus is located deep to the trapezius muscle in the posterior scapular region, extending from the supraspinous fossa of scapula to the proximal humerus.

Together with the other rotator cuff muscles, supraspinatus stabilizes the glenohumeral (shoulder) joint during the movements of the upper limb. Additionally, it assists in the abduction of the arm.

Supraspinatus is the most superior of the four rotator cuff muscles. It is a small triangular-shaped muscle, located on the posterior aspect of the scapula. It originates from the medial aspect of the supraspinous fossa, a concave depression located above the spine of the scapula.

The muscle fibers converge onto a tendon that runs inferior to the acromion of the scapula. After passing over the glenohumeral joint it inserts onto the superior facet on the greater tubercle of humerus.

It originates from the medial aspect of the supraspinous fossa, a concave depression located above the spine of the scapula.



Origin
Supraspinous fossa of scapula
Insertion
Greater tubercle of humerus

Action
Shoulder joint: abduction of arm, stabilization of the humeral head in the glenoid cavity
Innervation
Suprascapular nerve (C5, C6)
Blood supply
Suprascapular artery

Cards.title: Infraspinatus
Cards.content:
Origin
Infraspinous fossa of scapula
Insertion
Greater tubercle of humerus
Action
Shoulder joint: Arm external rotation; 
Stabilizes humeral head in glenoid cavity
Innervation
Suprascapular nerve (C5, C6)
Blood supply
Suprascapular artery, circumflex scapular arteries

Infraspinatus is a thick triangular muscle that occupies the majority of the dorsal surface of the scapula. It arises mostly from the infraspinous fossa of scapula, and connects it to the proximal humerus. 

Infraspinatus is one of the four rotator cuff muscles, alongside subscapularis, teres minor and supraspinatus muscles. As a part of the rotator cuff muscles, the main function of infraspinatus muscle is external rotation of the humerus, as well as stabilization of the glenohumeral, or shoulder joint.

Cards.title: Membrane lipid
Cards.content:
The structure of a cell membrane constitute of phosphorlipids, each phosphorlipids molecules consist of a polar head which contain Phosphate group, choline and glycerol, the Phosphate group is negatively charged and can easily interact with water hence gives the polar head  it's hydrophilic property

And the non-polar tail which consist of two fatty acid chains, saturated and unsaturated fatty chain which is hydrophobic

The hydrophilic head of the phosphorlipids faces the extracellular and intracellular environment of the cell while the hydrophobic is in-between hence the cell membrane is a bilayer structure.

Cards.title: Cell membrane:-: Integra protein
Cards.content:
Integral proteins serve various crucial functions in the cell membrane, including:

1.Transport: Some integral proteins such glucose transporters helps in transporting specific materials or molecules across the cell membrane 

2. Receptor sites: e.g They can also serve as receptor proteins, which bind to specific signaling molecules (ligands) and initiate cellular responses.

3. Cell adhesion: Integral proteins can be involved in cell-cell adhesion and cell-matrix interactions, helping cells adhere to each other and to the extracellular matrix.e.g integrins

4. Enzymatic activity: Some integral proteins have enzymatic functions, catalyzing specific biochemical reactions at the cell membrane.

5. Structural support: They contribute to the overall stability and structural integrity of the cell membrane.

Examples of integral proteins include 

1.ion channels, 

2. G protein-coupled receptors, transporters (e.g., glucose transporters), and 

3. integrins (cell adhesion proteins).

 These proteins play essential roles in maintaining the integrity and functionality of the cell membrane.

Cards.title: Integra & peripheral protein
Cards.content: Integral proteins are confined within the plasma membrane and cross the entire or partial thickness of the cell membrane, whereas peripheral proteins are confined only on the surface of the cell membrane

Cards.title: Cell membrane :-: peripheral protein
Cards.content:
Peripheral Proteins:

1. Kinases: Many protein kinases are peripheral proteins associated with the inner surface of the cell membrane. They participate in phosphorylation reactions, adding phosphate groups to other proteins, and thereby regulate various cellular processes.

2. Spectrin: This peripheral protein is found in the cytoskeleton and helps maintain the shape and stability of red blood cells. It interacts with the inner surface of the cell membrane.

3. Annexins: These are peripheral membrane proteins that bind to negatively charged phospholipids in the cell membrane, influencing processes like membrane repair and vesicle trafficking.

4. Glycoproteins: Some glycoproteins are peripheral proteins that have carbohydrate chains attached. They are involved in cell recognition, adhesion, and signaling.

5. Adaptor Proteins: These peripheral proteins link integral membrane proteins to various cellular processes. For example, they can connect cell surface receptors to intracellular signaling pathways.

Cards.title: Cytosol
Cards.content:
Cytosol is the semi-fluid, gel-like substance found within cells where various cellular activities take place. It surrounds organelles and is where many metabolic reactions occur.

organelles are typically embedded in the cytosol. Organelles are membrane-bound structures within a cell, and they are suspended within the cytosol. This arrangement allows for compartmentalization of different cellular functions and processes.

1. Triacylglycerol :-:
a. Triacylglycerols, or triglycerides, store energy for the body. Calories are stored in the form of triglycerides in the liver and adipose tissue of the body. Between meals, when the body needs energy, hormones trigger the release of triglycerides into the blood stream.
b. Triglycerides also help to insulate the body and protect vital organs.

2. Waxes :-: these are ester of long chains of fatty acid and long monohydric alcohol, a typical wax is acetyl palmitate which is an ester of acetyl alcohol and palmitic acid,

Cards.title: Calories
Cards.content:
Calories are the amount of energy released when your body breaks down (digests and absorbs) food. The more calories a food has, the more energy it can provide to your body.

It is a unit of measuring energy in the body
1 ATP releases 7.3 kilocalories of energy 
Hence 38 ATP releases 222.4 kcal

These are simple lipids convalently bond to other groups other than fatty acid and alcohol

They are complex structure of lipid that contains additional molecules or group other than alcohol and fatty acid convalently bonded to simple lipid , this lipids carry out very important function in human, including signalling , other metabolic activity, they are also components of the cell membrane 
e.g

2. Glycolipids :-: they contains fatty acid and carbohydrates, they are found on the cell membrane, and they play a role in recognition and signaling e.g cerebrosides and gangliosides

3. Sulfolipids

Cards.title: Derived lipids
Cards.content:
Derived lipids, also known as preformed lipids or modified lipids, are a category of lipids that are not directly involved in energy storage or structural functions like simple and compound lipids. Instead, they are derived from the hydrolysis or modification of simple or compound lipids and often serve specialized functions in the body. Here are some common examples of derived lipids:

1. Eicosanides
2. Steroids
3. Fat soluble vitamins
4. Lipid soluble pigment
5. Diacylglycerol
6. Fatty acids

Cards.title: Branched fatty acid
Cards.content:
Branched-chain fatty acids (BCFAs) are a type of fatty acid with one or more branches or methyl (CH3) groups along their hydrocarbon chain. These branches can occur at different positions along the carbon backbone. BCFAs are not as common as straight-chain fatty acids but are found in some biological organisms. Here are a few examples of branched-chain fatty acids:

1. **Isovaleric Acid:** Isovaleric acid is a branched-chain fatty acid with a single methyl group on the carbon chain. It has a branched structure and is found in trace amounts in some dairy products. It contributes to the distinctive odor of sweaty feet.

2. **Isobutyric Acid:** Isobutyric acid is another branched-chain fatty acid with a methyl group branching off the carbon chain. It's found in some cheeses and is partly responsible for their aroma.

3. **Phytanic Acid:** Phytanic acid is a branched-chain fatty acid with multiple methyl groups along its carbon chain. It's derived from phytol, a component of chlorophyll, and is found in the fat of ruminant animals. Accumulation of phytanic acid can lead to a metabolic disorder known as Refsum disease.

4. **Tuberculostearic Acid:** Tuberculostearic acid is a branched-chain fatty acid with a unique structure. It is produced by the bacterium Mycobacterium tuberculosis and is associated with the cell wall of this pathogen.

These branched-chain fatty acids have distinct chemical structures and can have specific functions in the organisms that produce or encounter them.

Cards.title: LDL VS HDL
Cards.content:
There are two main types of cholesterol: high-density lipoprotein (HDL) and low-density lipoprotein (LDL). Lipoproteins are made of fat and proteins. Cholesterol moves through your body while inside lipoproteins.

HDL is known as “good cholesterol” because it transports cholesterol to your liver to be released from your body. HDL helps rid your body of excess cholesterol so it’s less likely to end up in your arteries.

LDL is called “bad cholesterol” because it takes cholesterol to your arteries, where it can collect in your artery walls. Too much cholesterol in your arteries may lead to a buildup of plaque known as atherosclerosis. This can increase the risk of blood clots in your arteries.

If a blood clot breaks away and blocks an artery in your heart or brain, you may have a stroke or heart attack.

Plaque buildup may also reduce blood flow and oxygen to major organs. Oxygen deprivation to your organs or arteries may lead to kidney disease or peripheral arterial disease, in addition to a heart attack or stroke.

Cards.title: Definition of ER
Cards.content:
Endoplasmic reticulum is a network of interconnected Membranous tubules forming a cistern which is found within the cytoplasm of eukaryotic cells ,
And they  continuity of outer membrane of the nuclear envelope 
Within the cistern is called vacuoplasm/lumen while outside is called cystol/hyaloplasm

Cards.title: Ergastoplasm
Cards.content: Ergastoplasm is the alternate name of the endoplasmic reticulum. The granular endoplasmic reticulum is also known as ergatoplasm. The ER in which ribosomes are found on the cisternae which are involved in the synthesis of proteins and are transported by the membrane-bound vesicles to the extracellular space.

Cards.title: Function of rough endoplasmic
Cards.content:
1. Site for protein Synthesis -: the RER has ribosome attached to its cistern which Synthesized protein using  by translating the mRNA as that bind to it, the synthesizes protein then enters tge lumen of the RER

2. Protein folding and modifications :- the synthesizes proteins undergoes post-translational modification with the aid specific enzymes , such modifications which include
N-linked Glycosylation (which is addition of oligosaccharides to the protein specifically to the amine group of asparagine, by an enzyme called Oligosaccharyltransferases, to form glycoproteins), or disulphide bond formation etc, which is necessary for the efficiency of the protein structure.

3. Storage and transportation:-: 
The modified proteins are parkaged in a vesicle and transported to various cellular destination, some of the protein are sent to the golgi bodies (with the help of proteins called cop 2 which are attached to the vesicle, hence directing the vessicle to the golgi bodies)

Cards.title: Polyribosome
Cards.content:
Also called polysomes is cluster of ribosomes which simultaneously translates the same mRNA, producing multiple copies of the same protein from the same mRNA. 

This however is an efficient way of cells to produce large quantities of proteins quickly

Cards.title: Ribosomes docking proteins
Cards.content: Responsible for attaching (docking) a ribosome to a membrane by interacting with a signal particle attached to a ribosome destined to be membrane bound.

Cards.title: Smooth endoplasmic reticulum
Cards.content: This one of the organelles within cytoplasm of eukaryotic cells, it differ from rough endoplasmic reticulum due to the absence of  ribosomes giving a smooth appearance when viewed under the microscope. It is a site of lipid synthesis

Cards.title: Functions of Smooth endoplasmic reticulum
Cards.content:
1. Lipid metabolism:-: Smooth ER are sites for the Synthesis of lipid and fatty, the main molecule for lipid synthesis is acetyl COA which undergoes series of reactions with help certain enzymes to produce
a. Fatty acids (fatty acid synthase) :-: which can be used to produce triacylglycerols or can be used to generate ATP through beta oxidation
b. Phosphorlipids:-: an important components of cell membrane 
c. Cholesterol:-: which can be used
 I. To produce sex hormones, [ e.g smooth ER is richly present in testes and ovaries and the cholesterol Synthesized by the smooth endoplasmic reticulum is use to produce sex hormones such as testosterone by testes and ostrogen and progesterone by  ovaries]

ii. To produce steroids hormones [ e.g the adrenal cortex is rich with smooth endoplasmic reticulum, the cholesterol Synthesized by this smooth ER can be used produced steroid homones such as cortisol by zona fasciculata and Aldosterone made by zona glomerulata this are part of the adrenal grand]

iii. To produce lipoprotein
Iv.  bile acid for efficient emulsification of oil [ by the hepatocytes]
v. As a one of the components of cell membrane


2. Detoxification:-:  Smooth endoplasmic reticulum (especially in hepatocytes of the liver) contains enzyme called cytochrome p450 that helps in the detoxification of harmful drugs and toxin by metabolising those toxics into water soluble substance which can be easily be excreted through the kidney , this process is also called Biotransformation 

3. Calcium ion storage :-: the smooth endoplasmic reticulum present in smooth and cardiac muscle as sarcoplasmic reticulum serves as calcium ion reservoir which are very important in muscle contractions.

4. Carbohydrates metabolism:-: Smooth endoplasmic reticulum are also involved in carbohydrates metabolism, which includes the breakdown of glycogen (a storage form of Glucose) into glucose

5. Steroids hormones Synthesis:-: in endocrine gland such as the gland of adrenal and gonads, the smooth endoplasmic reticulum play a vital role in steroid hormone synthesis such as cortisol and testosterone 


6. Membrane Synthesis:-: Smooth endoplasmic reticulum also contribute in the Synthesis of cellular membrane including the membrane of golgi bodies and perioxome.

7.

Cards.title: Function of Smooth ER : Summary
Cards.content:
1. Lipid metabolism
2. Carbohydrates metabolism
3. Steroids hormones Synthesis 
4. Membrane Synthesis
5. Detoxification/Biotransformation 
6. Calcium ion reservoir/storage

Cards.content:

2. Plasma cells (B lymphocytes) . This are type of white blood cells that produces antibodies, they richly contains smooth ER that Synthesizes and post-translate proteins that functions as antibodies.

3. Endocrine cell 
4. Nerve cells

Cards.title: Definition of golgi body
Cards.content:
Golgi bodies also know as golgi apparatus or golgi complex is a cellular organelles found within the cytoplasm of eukaryotic cells near the nucleus and endoplasmic reticulum. It consist of series flattened and folded membrane bound sac called cisternae.
It an important role in modifications and packaging of proteins into a vessicle for transporting to various destination, which might be

 a. To the cell membrane to be incorporated as components of cell membrane
b. Out of the cell
c. To lysosomes

Golgi body has two faces
a. Cis face: it faces the endoplasmic reticulum, it's convex face of the golgi body where protein and other materials enter the golgi body

b. Trans face : this is concave face , where materials like, modified proteins,lipids etc are transported to their various destination.

Cards.title: Function of golgi bodies (detail)
Cards.content:
1. Protein modifications :-: proteins from endoplasmic reticulum are transported in a vessicle directed by protein called Cop 2 to the golgi bodies through the cis face of the golgi bodies where further modified and folded for their efficiency, such modifications includes
a. Trimming of the N-linked oligosaccharides
b.

Cards.title: Definition of cell cycle
Cards.content:
Cell cycle is the series of event or process that takes place In a cell as it replicates and divides into two daughters, this process are 4 staged process which includes
1. G-1 phase 
2. S-phase 
3. G-2 phase
4. Mitosis

Cards.title: Phase in cell cycle
Cards.content:
1. InterPhase
   a. G1 phase

Cards.title: G1 phase
Cards.content:
This a preparatory period as the cell prepares it self for the cell cycle

1. The cell Synthesizes proteins and enzymes that are need for the cell cycle
2. The cell makes more organelles that will be sufficient to the two daughters cell
3. Cell checkes for any damage especially in the DNA for repair, if the DNA is damaged beyond repair, the cell might enter opoptosis(cell death)
4. Cells also carry it normal function 
5. After completing the above before going into the next phase the cell enters a critical checkpoint called G1/S checkpoint. Where the cell assess it's  integrity to know whether to proceed with the cell cycle or not
