Cards.title: Definition of lipoprotein
Cards.content: Lipoproteins are complex molecules composed of lipid and protein known as Apolipoprotein that help in the transportation of  lipids such as triglycerides and cholesterol from dietary  or specific organ where they are synthesized through the blood stream to peripheral tissues

Cards.title: Structure of lipoprotein
Cards.content:
Lipoproteins is made up of 
1. core composed of hydrophobic lipids such as cholesterol ester and triglycerides hence know as hydrophobic core
2. Hydrophilic shell :-: the hydrophobic core is surrounded by shell composed of hydrophilic lipid such phosphorlipids , free cholesterol and also proteins called Apoproteins

This makes the lipoproteins polar and also enhance the hydration of the shell this because the negative nitrogen ion in phosphorlipids forms ionic bond with hydrogen ion in water,  

The Apolipoprotein also enhance the solubility of lipoprotein

Cards.title: Types of lipoproteins
Cards.content:
1. Chylomicrons
2. Chylomicrons Remnant 
3. Very low density lipoproteins (VLDL)
4. VLDL Remnant / Intermediate density lipoproteins (IDL)
5. Low density lipoproteins (LDL)
6. High density lipoproteins (HDL)

N.B Chylomicrons is the largest lipoproteins with least density while HDL is the smallest lipoproteins with the highest density

Cards.title: Basics of lipid transport
Cards.content:
1. Lipids are non polar substance and because of this they cannot be transported alone through the blood, a transport medium for lipid which is a polar environment 
2. Hence lipoprotein play a vital role in the transportation of lipids by forming a polar shell composed of hydrophilic lipids and Apolipoprotein around the non polar lipids. Therefore lipid can now be transported through the polar environment which is blood

Cards.title: Chylomicrons
Cards.content:
Characteristics 
1. Chylomicrons is the largest lipoproteins of diameter of about 75 - 100 nanometers
2. It has the lowest protein to lipid ratio, contains 90% lipids, hence it has the lowest density 
3. It contains more triglycerides than cholesterol in its hydrophobic core

SYNTHESIS 
1. They are synthesized by the 
epithelial cell of the small intestine via exogenous lipoproteins pathway and secreted into the lymphatic vessels that drains the gut and then enter the blood stream via subclavian vein
2

APOPROTEINS
1. ApoB-48
2. ApoE
3. ApoC-2 ( which activates capillary lipoproteins lipase)

Cards.title: Lipoproteins lipase(LPL)
Cards.content:
This is an enzyme Synthesized in the adipose tissue, skeletal muscle, smooth muscle and acinar cell of mammary tissue and located on the surface of  capillaries endothelial cells

As Chylomicrons level in the blood increase, a lipoproteins that carries tryglycerol to adipose, skeletal and smooth muscle and mammary gland, the insulin hormone stimulate the secretion of LDL which is activated by ApoC-2 on the chylomicrons. This isoenzyme when activated becomes an enzyme hydrolyse the triglycerides in the chylomicrons into free glycerol and fatty acids

Muscles cell oxidizes the fatty acid to generate energy, Adipocytes and mammary gland stores  as triglycerides in case of lactating breast can be used in production of milk in mammary gland

Cards.title: Chylomicrons Remnant
Cards.content:
This is chylomicrons with depleted tryglycerides, it has lost its ApoC-2, hence containing only ApoB-48 and ApoE

ApoE binds to the receptor on the plasma membrane of the liver cells, transporting the Chylomicrons into the cell via receptor mediated endocytosis,

The lipids and proteins from Chylomicrons are use in the Synthesis of VLDL and LDL

Cards.title: Very Low Density lipoproteins
Cards.content:
APOPROTEINS present
a. ApoE
b. ApoC-2
c. ApoB-100


This is a lipoproteins that carries triglycerides from the liver to peripheral tissues e.g adipose tissue, skeletal and cardiac muscle and lactating breast

When carbohydrates from diet exceeds the fuel requirement of the body, the liver coverts these carbohydrates to triglycerides and in combination with free and esterified cholesterol, phosphorlipids and a major Apolipoprotein ApoB-100 are packaged to form nascent VLDL

This VLDL are secreted in to the blood stream (via endogenous pathway of lipoprotein metabolism) where they pick up ApoC-11 and ApoE hence becoming mature VLDL

VLDL are then transported from hepatic vein to capillaries of Adipocytes, skeletal and cardiac muscle and mammary gland, the Lipoproteins lipase is the activated by ApoC-2, and it hydrolyse the triglycerides in VLDL into free fatty acid and glycerol, these fatty acids are oxidized to produce fuel by muscle cells, used in resynthesis of triglycerides by Adipocytes, and used to produce milk by lactating breast 

These VLDL are now largely depleted of their triglycerides hence giving rise to Intermediate Density lipoproteins (IDL) which are taking up by the liver through the bunding of ApoE of IDL to Apo E receptor on the plasma membrane of hepatocytes.

Note: ApoC-3 is a minor Apolipoprotein on both VLDL and chylomicrons that inhibited lipoproteins lipase

Cards.title: IDL (intermediate density lipoproteins)
Cards.content:
When VLDL is depleted of its triglycerides, it becomes IDL which is now taken to the liver for degradation and Synthesis of other lipoproteins 

APOPROTEINS
ApoB-100, ApoE

Cards.title: LDL
Cards.content:
This are lipoproteins that richly contains cholesterol whose principal function is to carry cholesterol both free and esterified to peripheral tissues such as adrenocortical cells ( where they are use to Synthesize steroid hormone) and gonads (where they are use to Synthesize sex hormones like testosterone)
, most of the cholesterol found in blood plasma is associated with LDL

They are generated from IDL a specific VLDL Remnant, by the action of hepatic glyceride lipase within the hepatic sinusoid, by the removal of additional triglycerides from IDL,

APOPROTEINS PRESENT
ApoB-100 only

Clinical
When their to much LDL in the blood, it begins to form fatty deposit in the artery called plaque which narrows the artery reducing blood flow through the artery increasing the of certain disease, common place where this plaque are formed 
1. Coronary artery which feeds the heart and this might the risk of heart attack 
2. Cortid artery around the neck that supplies blood to the brain, this can Increase the risk of a stroke

Cards.title: HDL
Cards.content:
This is very dense lipoproteins that primary takes excess cholesterol from arteries and cell to the liver through reverse cholesterol transport where they are removed hence reducing the risk of arterial disease etc

APOLIPOPROTEIN PRESENT 
1. ApoA-1 
2. ApoA-2 
(Major)
3. ApoC-1
4. ApoC-2

HDL are synthesized and secreted by the liver and they nascent HDL, as they pick up cholesterol and their core is progressively filled with cholesterol they take a globular shape and become a mature HDL

There is a protein called ATP binding cassette protein 1(ABCA1), in the cell which uses ATP hydrolysis to move cholestero l from inner to outer membrane where they are picked up by HDL

This free cholesterol is left like that will go back to the cell, hence they are trapped with the help of an enzyme called LCAT(lecithin cholesterol AcylTransferase) synthesized and secreted by the liver, this enzyme catalysed the transfer of fatty acid from second lecithin(phosphatidycholine) in the  hydrophilic shell of HDL to 3-hydroxyl group of cholesterol forming cholesterol ester which now migrates to the core.

FATE OF HDL CHOLESTEROL
The mature HDL then interact with Scavenger receptors B-1 (SR-B1) present in most cells via ApoA-1 transferring its cholesterol into the cell , depleted of its cholesterol move back into circulation.

Cards.title: Function of Apolipoproteins
Cards.content:
1. They form part of the structure of lipoproteins, mostly found on the hydrophilic shell of lipoproteins e.g ApoC-11, ApoE etc

2. They act as a co-factor to certain enzymes e.g ApoC-2  for Lipoproteins lipase and ApoA-1 for lecithin cholesterol AcylTransferase.

3. They act as a ligands which interact with lipoproteins receptors in tissue  e.g ApoE and ApoB-100 in LDL , ApoA-1 in HDL

Cards.title: APOPROTEINS and their functions
Cards.content:
1. ApoA-1 : it is Synthesized in the liver and intestines and it is major Apolipoprotein of HDL proteins that made up about 70% of HDL protein
a. It enables HDL to interact with     ATP-binding cassette protein 1 (ABCA1) and scavenger receptor B1 (SR-B1)
b. It activates lecithin-cholesterol AcylTransferase (which esterifies cholesterol)

ApoA-1 is mostly associated with low risk of arterial disease/atherosclerosis 

2. ApoC-2 : this is present in Chylomicrons and VLDL , it activates lipoproteins lipase which hydrolysis triacylglycerides into free glycerol and fatty acid .

3. ApoE : present in Chylomicrons, VLDL and IDL, it interact with ApoE receptor on liver membrane hence mediating the uptake of chylomicrons Remnant and IDL into the liver cells through receptor medated endocytosis 


3. ApoB-100 :-:  is found in LDL as the only structural lipoproteins, and it facilitate the transport of cholesterol to peripheral tissues, and often associated with atherosclerosis, it also found in VLDL and IDL

4. ApoC-111 : found in VLDL and IDL , it inhibites lipoproteins lipase, hence it delays the clearance of triglycerides rich lipoprotein from the blood

5. ApoB-48 : it is one of the structural Apolipoproteins in Chylomicrons

Cards.title: Oral cavity and Stomach
Cards.content:
1. The sublingual salivary gland at back of the tongue and the parotid at side of the face anterior to the ear secrets a lingual lipase 

2. Chief cells in the stomach secrets gastric lipase

Both acts on of triglycerides in the food breaking down the ester linkage to form fatty acid and monoacylglycerides

These digestion is limited due to the insolubility of the substrate.

3. The pancreas also secrets phosphorlipase A2. Which hydrolyse phosphorlipids in diet , and cholesterol esterase which hydrolyse cholesterol ester

Cards.title: Intestines
Cards.content: 1. As food enters the intestine an hormone called cholecystokinin which triggers the secretion of bile acid from gall bladder and pancreatic lipase from pancreas

Cards.title: Gall bladder and pancreas
Cards.content:
1. Gall bladder stores bile Synthesized by the liver, the cystic duct of the bladder fused with the pancreatic duct of the pancreas to form apado pancreatic ampulla which is surrounded by a ring of smooth muscle called sphincter of oddibor paddle of pancreatic sphincter.

On relaxation of the smooth muscle the bile and pancreatic lipase are secreted.
